plan_a_minimal_move.name: Plan A - Stability First
plan_a_minimal_move.philosophy: Minimal turnover, reduce concentration, improve cash buffer

improvements.single_name_exposure: NVDA reduced from 17.1% to 14.8% (incl. ETF overlap)

pros: Low turnover minimizes transaction costs and tax impact
Maintains core positions and investment thesis
SCHD adds quality dividend diversification outside tech
Cash buffer doubled for defensive positioning
cons: Sharpe ratio still well below 1.0 target (only reaches 0.59)
Still vulnerable to tech sector selloff

plan_b_offensive_rebalance.name: Plan B - Balanced Growth
plan_b_offensive_rebalance.philosophy: Eliminate sector redundancy, add diversification, improve risk-adjusted returns
plan_b_offensive_rebalance.target_audience: Growth-focused investors willing to optimize structure

improvements.sector_diversification: Added Value tilt (VTV 7%), reduced semiconductor redundancy

pros: Sharpe ratio improves 60% (0.45 → 0.72) - significant risk-adjusted improvement
QQQ provides diversified tech exposure (100 stocks vs single names)
VTV adds value/defensive characteristics, low correlation to growth
Cash buffer doubled to 10% - meaningful dry powder
Tech concentration reduced to 58% - more balanced
Reduces JEPQ (option-capped upside) while keeping JEPI for income
cons: Complete exit from SOXX may trigger capital gains if held at profit
Adds two new positions to manage (QQQ, VTV)

rationale.eliminate_soxx: SOXX creates 16.47% total NVDA exposure (15% direct + 1.47% via SOXX holdings). By keeping NVDA direct, we maintain conviction but eliminate redundancy. QQQ provides semiconductor exposure via ~10% allocation to NVDA/AVGO/AMD without concentration.
rationale.reduce_jepq: JEPQ caps upside via covered calls while taking full downside. In AI boom scenario, NVDA could rise 50% but JEPQ captures only 15-18%. Reducing to 5% maintains some option income while freeing capital for uncapped upside.
rationale.add_qtq: Provides broad Nasdaq-100 exposure (100 holdings) with lower single-stock risk. Captures tech upside without concentration. Expense ratio 0.20% is reasonable.
rationale.add_vtv: Value tilt provides diversification from growth-heavy portfolio. Typically includes Financials, Healthcare, Energy - sectors absent from current portfolio. Historical correlation to tech ~0.50, provides defensive characteristics.
rationale.increase_sgov: 10% cash buffer allows tactical opportunities, reduces portfolio beta, provides cushion in drawdowns. At 4.2% yield, not a drag on returns.

reasoning: Sharpe ratio improvement (0.72 vs 0.59) justifies higher turnover
Addresses fundamental structural issues (semiconductor redundancy, sector concentration)
Better downside protection (10% cash vs 9%) and sector diversification
More aligned with 'moderate' risk budget - Plan A remains too aggressive
Long-term portfolio efficiency gains outweigh short-term transaction costs
execution_notes: Review tax implications of SOXX sale - consider tax-loss harvesting if underwater
Execute in two tranches: (1) Sell SOXX/JEPQ, buy SGOV/VTV, (2) Add QQQ, increase MSFT
Consider limit orders for illiquid positions to minimize slippage
Time execution around earnings releases (NVDA earnings Nov 19) to avoid volatility
caveats: Target Sharpe ratio of 1.0 is aspirational - would require 50%+ fixed income allocation
Both plans assume historical correlations persist - may break in regime changes
Option income (JEPI/JEPQ) is variable and depends on volatility levels
Plans optimize for risk-adjusted returns, not maximum absolute returns
